description.narrative: Nearly twenty years after the civil war, the health system in Sierra Leone is still battling with major challenges to deliver quality health services, especially in the rural areas. Health facilities are dilapidated with few under qualified health personnel. Drug supply to rural health centers is delayed, inconsistent and at times inadequate and lacks essential drugs. Poverty remains widespread with more than 60% of the population living on less than US$ 1.25 a day. Unemployment among young people and illiteracy levels, especially among women and adolescent girls, are high. Although Sierra Leone has made considerable progress in consolidating peace and democracy, the country was hard-hit by Ebola in 2014 with more than 3,500 deaths and the appearance of Covid19 in March 2020. As of the 30th August 2021, the country has registered over 3,000 confirmed cases and more than 70 deaths (Source- NaCoVERC – SL).

•Strengthening Savings methodology and women’s mobilization and empowerment which was very impactful during the Health Legacy project through refresher trainings on the methodology and introduction of mobile technology (mobile money). •Strengthening Gender Model Family, Gender and Inclusion trainings for existing groups to enhance effectiveness and to mobilize and co-opt other families. •Strengthen the local Facility Management Committees for a more equitable and responsive health system at the community level.
